Says Government Direction
Of Youth Education Menaces Free Scientific Work

Attacks Oath Laws
Political Interference Tends
To Lead To More Assaults
On Freedom, He Says
Rapping the government for "giving direction to the education of
youth

and

thereby

menacing the

freedom of scientific inquiry," Dr.
Isaiah Bowman, president of the
Johns Hopkins University, delivered
an address to the National Academy
of Sciences, assembled at Charlottesville, Virginia, on Tuesday evening.
"Today the threat to freedom in
scientific inquiry takes on a new
guise. Government has taken advantage of our perilous need to give direction to the education of youth
through the expenditure of public
funds administered by men who are
but sounding boards for political
leaders."

Bowman did not say whether he referred directly to the Washington
which is spending

Administration

in state legislatures also received severe criticism from the president.
"That high-sounding phrase, the
oath of allegiance, is but the forerunner of other seditious phrases
that represent an assault on freedom and the debasement of democratic ideals," he stated.
"Further assaults on freedom will
inevitably result," Dr. Bowman declared in closing his address.

German Economist
Addresses-Classes
Dr. Stroemer Discusses His Experiments In Cooperative Community Living
Dr. Broadus Mitchell's classes in
Economic History and Elements of
Economics were addressed last week
by Dr. Alfred Stroemer, famed European economist, who is in this
country in an advisory capacity to
Harry Hopkins in making a study
in rural rehabpitation.
His experiments in unemployment
relief through planned communities
and his plans for experimentation in
this country were the main thesis of
Dr. Stroemer's talk. He emphasized
again and again that there is no reason why this country should ever
suffer from a depression. "Your
country has the greatest treasure in
the world; free land. There is no excuse for a depression in a country
which possesses free land."
The plan which Dr. Stroemer is interested in, calls for a cooperative
community in which production is
for use, not profit, and each man
works at the job for which he is best
suited. Dr. Stroemer closed his talk
by telling the class, "The greatest
theory that you students in economics
can learn is that the way to succeed
in life is by cooperation."

Friday, November 22, 1935

The Spiked Shoe Society

About this time of the year, when winter clothing
is being taken out of its secret hiding places, I think it
is not only proper but apropos that we should hear
from Grandpa Overcoat. Grandpa was thought about
during the first cold spell in October, but the maid
who had put him away, had to have the janitor help
her figure out by a process of elimination, exactly
which cupboard he was in. Tell us all about it, Grartapa.
"That day in April when I was placed out in the
yard to air, just after I had returned from the cleaners, I knew that I was in for a period of hell and starvation. While hanging there in the yard, I suddenly
felt a moth climb under the flap of my left pocket. I
broke out in a hot and cold sweat alternately. I felt
nauseous. The fright and dread of the thought of having
this deadly enemy on my person all during those lonely
months of solitary confinement, gnawing at my entrails, was almost too much for me to bear. Perhaps
he would be discovered and exterminated. But alas, fate
was not so kind. Sometime about the first of June, by
my figuring, I felt the moth crawl out from under the
flap to a more conspicuous place, and gorge himself
with my flesh. Cessation of the biting into my side told
me the moth slept. About a month later I felt him
awaken and crawl to a still more conspicuous place .for
his final meal. He was such a gluttonous fool that he
succumbed to a very severe atttak of dyspepsia, and fell
from my side to the floor. I don't want to bore you
with my story any longer, but what a row the master
made about economy when he discovered those holes
in my side."

GUILD
The Guild Theatre continues to present three times weekly, Gilbert and
Sullivan's The Yeoman of the Guard.
This delightful operetta will continue until the beginning of December,
at which time it wll be replaced with
a smart British play, London Assurance.
The operettas are given Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday nights.
Included in the cast of the operetta are Lester Wolf, William Christopher; Omar Pancoast, Joseph Kendrick, Edmund Leonard, A. Russell
Slagle, and others. The production
was under the direction of T. M.
Cushing.

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 22, 1935

Jay Booters Out Division A Crown
JaysFootballersHopefulOf A
Lone Season Victory By Win ToBreak Western To Phi Psi; S.P.E.
Maryland Kickers Defeated In Final
Over Lizzies In Final Game Game To Be Played
Prior To Undefeated Pi Lams Trounce
Ford Eleven More Aggressive; Tiernan Stellar Quarterback, In The Line-Up

Match To Be Spirited
Jays Have Added Incentive;
Last Game For Pasarew,
Phillips, And McGuire
Tomorrow afternoon when it meets
the Scarlet and Black eleven of Haverford College, the Hopkins football
team will bring the curtain down
Upon its current abbreviated season.
The Jays are determined not to finish their schedule without a victory
and intend to subdue the Pennsylvania institution's aggregation.
The visiting eleven has had a disappointing season as far as its rooters are concerned, for tilts were lost
to Lehigh, Susquehanna, Dickinson
and Randolph-Macon. Victories were
registered over Wesleyan and Hamilton. However, the Lizzies will be materially strengthened by the return
to action of Bill Tiernan, stellar
quarterback, and elusive open-field
runner, who has been out of action
almost the entire season because of
injuries sustained in an early encounter. Tiernan has as his running
mate, "Chuck" Holzer, 200-pound
halfback, who besides being the fastest man on the squad, hits the line
With pile-driving force. The punting
is done by Herb Taylor, who holds
the other halfback position.
Fords Lacks Subs
On the lines, the Haverford eleven
prides itself on the playing of Arthur "Sugar" Kane and Charles
"Chick" Fraser. The former is the
captain and holds down one of the
Wing posts, at which berth he has
much ability and experience. The
latter is another veteran, taking care
of the right guard position, which
he does capably, and is regarded as
the "pepper pot" of the forward wall.
Haverford Lacking In Subs
Haverford's essential weakness is
the lack of reserve material. It is to
this cause that Coach Roy Randall
attributes the loss of contests. Time
after time when it was necessary to
remove a first team man from a
game, the subs were not able to fill
the shoes of the regulars. However,
with the entire squad in fine condition, and not at all fatigued, for
Haverford had no game scheduled last
week, Coach Randall expects his boys
to put up a fine showing.
Jays To Have Regular Line-Up
In the St. John's fracas, the Darleymen showed themselves to be a
spirited squad, fighting until the final
whistle. This same attitude has dominated the practices all during the
week. The coaches have attempted
to iron out the flaws observed in
previous frays, and have put the
squad through frequent scrimmaging,
in order to attain this end. The main
task was to improve the offensive
play, since the Hopkins gridders have
a very effective defense, especially
against passes, in which Kahl plays
a prominent part.
The Jays will most likely start the
game with the same men that entered the contest against St. John's. This
includes Schmidt and Swindell, both
of whom performed admirably in the
last tussle, at the wing posts; McGuire and Pinsky, the fast and big
men of the line, at the tickles, with
Ellis certain to see action; Day and
Phillips, freshman and senior, respectively, holding down the guard
berths; Halbert, steady and strong,
performing at the pivot position. At
the opening kick-off the backfield
will most likely consist of Captain
Pasarew at quarterback, whose kicking helped the Jays out of many uncomfortable positions in the last encounter, and whose open field running was one of the highlights of
the day; Kahl, who proved his merit
by intercepting several passes on
Saturday at one halfback position;
and Vincenti, whose deadly tackling
and steady pep brace the line considerably, at the other halfback position; and Graziano, whose unstoppable plunging made him the outstanding man on the field in the tilt
With the Johnnies.
Three members of the team, namely Pasarew, Otts Phillips, and McGuire, will have added incentive since
these three men, all seniors, will be
Performing in their last football game
for the Hopkins, and consequently
can be expected to put up an excellent exhibition.

Jay Walks
By DAVID CAPLAN

Football Team To
Draw Curtain Tomorrow
The Johns Hopkins football team
closes an anything-but-successful season when it meets the Haverford
eleven tomorrow
at
Homewood
Field.
For the first time this season, the
Jays will go into a game with a
fifty-fifty chance of emerging the
victor, and this chance will be accentuated by an earnest spirit on the
part of the team to end the season
with a victory. True enough, the
team has had plenty of spirit through
out the campaign, so here's hoping
it earns the reward it merits by
gaining a victory tomorrow.

RONALD LEVI
The "Ox' . . . Ronny's a Friends
product of '28 . . . Athletics at
Friends—football, lacrosse and swimming . . . Came to good ol' Johnny
Hopkins the following fall . .. At
Homewood messed around on gridiron. . Walked off with two "Hs"
as varsity guard . . All-Maryland
selection in '31 . . . Some messin',
aye? . . Played lacrosse, also . . .
Warbled for Music Club for three
years . . . Initiated as "0. 1/ K.er"
in junior year . . . D. U. claims him
as theirs . . . During senior year at
Hopkins, "Ox" held four major offices: president of Student Council,
Music Club, and D. U. and 0. D. K.
secretary . . . Received B.S. in '32
since when he has been doing grad
work in chemistry ... Also has been
doing assistant coaching work in
football and fall lacrosse.

Frosh-Sophs To
Start Football
Practice Soon
Equipment To Be Given Out
Monday; Lotz, Mallonee
To Coach Soph, Frosh
Frosh-Soph rivalry will come to a
head next week when the football
teams representing the two classes
begin practice for the game which
the Athletic Department has arranged as an introduction to their traditional rivalry.
Coaches Gard Mallonee and Ed
Lotz of the frosh and sophs, respectively have become quite a bit "het
up" over the prospects of their teams.
As yet neither team is a known
quantity. Both coaches are pretty
confident of their team's chances—
naturally, they have to be, since
someone must maintain faith or nobody else will. This attitude on the
part of Mallonee and Lotz is quite
different than that employed by other football coaches. Lou Little of Columbia fame and Gil Dobie, formerly of Cornell, are two mentors who
are directly opposite our confident
coaches. Little and Dobie were always bemoaning their teams' chances
—but not so with our up-and-coming
members of the coaching staff—Lotz
and Mallonee.
First Year For Game
To get back to the game between
the frosh and sophs. This is one of
the first years that such a game has
ever been played. To all indications,
support is far from lacking.
The
members of each class are anxious to
win the game, since such a victory
will be the first blood drawn in the
rivalry.
Later developments between the classes is to come during
Hell Week which comes sometime in
May.
Starting Monday the coaches and
managers of both teams will be at
the gym to hand out equipment to

Hereditary Influence Factor
Children Endangered
Following Dr. Macht's address, a
paper was presented by Dr. Raymond Pearl, of the Johns Hopkins
Medical School, who said that he
had "found that a person is about
four times as likely to have tuberculosis if both his parents had it
than if neither did.
"I mean definitely to overthrow
beliefs that the extra number of tubercular children in such families
get it by contact rather than by inheritance. I analyzed tuberculosis in
564 families, numbering 3,608 per-

"The regular increase in the offspring percentage as the amount of
parental tuberculosis increases seems
impossible of rational explanation
on any other basis than that of hereditary influence.

was there, and every evening thereafter I was taken to the local beer
joint. I slept in Dick Snibbe's bed in
Pinkney Hall, as he was in the infirmary as a result of the attack on
Hopkins the previous Monday.
Big Time Friday
Friday night we had a big time.
All the freshmen and the two Hopkins boys dressed in pajamas for a
snake dance before the bonfire.
Burghardt and I led the procession,
which went down to cheer the Naval
Academy and they in turn cheered
us. The bonfire itself was about
thirty feet square and three stories
high and gave a great amount of
heat and light. It was still burning
at noon the next day.
The next day Jimmy Gunn drove
me back to Baltimore, and I must
say I was a trifle sorry to leave the
place where I had had such a good
time. In conclusion let me say that
the St. John's boys treated me very
well, as they went out of their way
to entertain me and introduced me to
everybody. The little bit of horseplay
to which I was subjected only added
to my enjoyment.

Rifle Club Members To
Record Weekly Scores
Preparing for the coming season,
which begins in December, members
of the Rifle Club are firing for record during this week. Records will
be kept of the best scores in each of
the three positions—prone, kneeling,
and standing. The ten men with the
best averages for these positions will
shoot for the Hopkins rifle team in
its first match, scheduled for December 14.
Returning members of the team
from last year are P. W. Guild, president of the club; Don Noonan, and
Henry Leber. All members are expected to file their scores with Sergeant Perry, so that an accurate account of their improvement from
week to week can be kept.
Later in the season, probably in
March and April, two or three shoulder to shoulder matches for the
Ra-citern Intercollegiates will be
scheduled with Maryland, Gettysburg, and the Naval Academy.

German Economist
Addresses-Classes
Dr. Stroemer Discusses His Experiments In Cooperative Community Living
Dr. Broadus Mitchell's classes in
Economic History and Elements of
Economics were addressed last week
by Dr. Alfred Stroemer, famed European economist, who is in this
country in an advisory capacity to
Harry Hopkins in making a study
in rural rehabpitation.
His experiments in unemployment
relief through planned communities
and his plans for experimentation in
this country were the main thesis of
Dr. Stroemer's talk. He emphasized
again and again that there is no reason why this country should ever
suffer from a depression. "Your
country has the greatest treasure in
the world; free land. There is no excuse for a depression in a country
which possesses free land."
The plan which Dr. Stroemer is interested in, calls for a cooperative
community in which production is
for use, not profit, and each man
works at the job for which he is best
suited. Dr. Stroemer closed his talk
by telling the class, "The greatest
theory that you students in economics
can learn is that the way to succeed
in life is by cooperation."

Friday, November 22, 1935

The Spiked Shoe Society

About this time of the year, when winter clothing
is being taken out of its secret hiding places, I think it
is not only proper but apropos that we should hear
from Grandpa Overcoat. Grandpa was thought about
during the first cold spell in October, but the maid
who had put him away, had to have the janitor help
her figure out by a process of elimination, exactly
which cupboard he was in. Tell us all about it, Grartapa.
"That day in April when I was placed out in the
yard to air, just after I had returned from the cleaners, I knew that I was in for a period of hell and starvation. While hanging there in the yard, I suddenly
felt a moth climb under the flap of my left pocket. I
broke out in a hot and cold sweat alternately. I felt
nauseous. The fright and dread of the thought of having
this deadly enemy on my person all during those lonely
months of solitary confinement, gnawing at my entrails, was almost too much for me to bear. Perhaps
he would be discovered and exterminated. But alas, fate
was not so kind. Sometime about the first of June, by
my figuring, I felt the moth crawl out from under the
flap to a more conspicuous place, and gorge himself
with my flesh. Cessation of the biting into my side told
me the moth slept. About a month later I felt him
awaken and crawl to a still more conspicuous place .for
his final meal. He was such a gluttonous fool that he
succumbed to a very severe atttak of dyspepsia, and fell
from my side to the floor. I don't want to bore you
with my story any longer, but what a row the master
made about economy when he discovered those holes
in my side."

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 22, 1935

Jay Booters Out Division A Crown
JaysFootballersHopefulOf A
Lone Season Victory By Win ToBreak Western To Phi Psi; S.P.E.
Maryland Kickers Defeated In Final
Over Lizzies In Final Game Game To Be Played
Prior To Undefeated Pi Lams Trounce
Ford Eleven More Aggressive; Tiernan Stellar Quarterback, In The Line-Up

Match To Be Spirited
Jays Have Added Incentive;
Last Game For Pasarew,
Phillips, And McGuire
Tomorrow afternoon when it meets
the Scarlet and Black eleven of Haverford College, the Hopkins football
team will bring the curtain down
Upon its current abbreviated season.
The Jays are determined not to finish their schedule without a victory
and intend to subdue the Pennsylvania institution's aggregation.
The visiting eleven has had a disappointing season as far as its rooters are concerned, for tilts were lost
to Lehigh, Susquehanna, Dickinson
and Randolph-Macon. Victories were
registered over Wesleyan and Hamilton. However, the Lizzies will be materially strengthened by the return
to action of Bill Tiernan, stellar
quarterback, and elusive open-field
runner, who has been out of action
almost the entire season because of
injuries sustained in an early encounter. Tiernan has as his running
mate, "Chuck" Holzer, 200-pound
halfback, who besides being the fastest man on the squad, hits the line
With pile-driving force. The punting
is done by Herb Taylor, who holds
the other halfback position.
Fords Lacks Subs
On the lines, the Haverford eleven
prides itself on the playing of Arthur "Sugar" Kane and Charles
"Chick" Fraser. The former is the
captain and holds down one of the
Wing posts, at which berth he has
much ability and experience. The
latter is another veteran, taking care
of the right guard position, which
he does capably, and is regarded as
the "pepper pot" of the forward wall.
Haverford Lacking In Subs
Haverford's essential weakness is
the lack of reserve material. It is to
this cause that Coach Roy Randall
attributes the loss of contests. Time
after time when it was necessary to
remove a first team man from a
game, the subs were not able to fill
the shoes of the regulars. However,
with the entire squad in fine condition, and not at all fatigued, for
Haverford had no game scheduled last
week, Coach Randall expects his boys
to put up a fine showing.
Jays To Have Regular Line-Up
In the St. John's fracas, the Darleymen showed themselves to be a
spirited squad, fighting until the final
whistle. This same attitude has dominated the practices all during the
week. The coaches have attempted
to iron out the flaws observed in
previous frays, and have put the
squad through frequent scrimmaging,
in order to attain this end. The main
task was to improve the offensive
play, since the Hopkins gridders have
a very effective defense, especially
against passes, in which Kahl plays
a prominent part.
The Jays will most likely start the
game with the same men that entered the contest against St. John's. This
includes Schmidt and Swindell, both
of whom performed admirably in the
last tussle, at the wing posts; McGuire and Pinsky, the fast and big
men of the line, at the tickles, with
Ellis certain to see action; Day and
Phillips, freshman and senior, respectively, holding down the guard
berths; Halbert, steady and strong,
performing at the pivot position. At
the opening kick-off the backfield
will most likely consist of Captain
Pasarew at quarterback, whose kicking helped the Jays out of many uncomfortable positions in the last encounter, and whose open field running was one of the highlights of
the day; Kahl, who proved his merit
by intercepting several passes on
Saturday at one halfback position;
and Vincenti, whose deadly tackling
and steady pep brace the line considerably, at the other halfback position; and Graziano, whose unstoppable plunging made him the outstanding man on the field in the tilt
With the Johnnies.
Three members of the team, namely Pasarew, Otts Phillips, and McGuire, will have added incentive since
these three men, all seniors, will be
Performing in their last football game
for the Hopkins, and consequently
can be expected to put up an excellent exhibition.

Jay Walks
By DAVID CAPLAN

Football Team To
Draw Curtain Tomorrow
The Johns Hopkins football team
closes an anything-but-successful season when it meets the Haverford
eleven tomorrow
at
Homewood
Field.
For the first time this season, the
Jays will go into a game with a
fifty-fifty chance of emerging the
victor, and this chance will be accentuated by an earnest spirit on the
part of the team to end the season
with a victory. True enough, the
team has had plenty of spirit through
out the campaign, so here's hoping
it earns the reward it merits by
gaining a victory tomorrow.

RONALD LEVI
The "Ox' . . . Ronny's a Friends
product of '28 . . . Athletics at
Friends—football, lacrosse and swimming . . . Came to good ol' Johnny
Hopkins the following fall . .. At
Homewood messed around on gridiron. . Walked off with two "Hs"
as varsity guard . . All-Maryland
selection in '31 . . . Some messin',
aye? . . Played lacrosse, also . . .
Warbled for Music Club for three
years . . . Initiated as "0. 1/ K.er"
in junior year . . . D. U. claims him
as theirs . . . During senior year at
Hopkins, "Ox" held four major offices: president of Student Council,
Music Club, and D. U. and 0. D. K.
secretary . . . Received B.S. in '32
since when he has been doing grad
work in chemistry ... Also has been
doing assistant coaching work in
football and fall lacrosse.
Question: Why the name "Ox"?
Answer: With a build like a veritable powerhouse and with a pair of

2 inches of good
tape measure to loop, is it any wonder?

Frosh-Soph rivalry will come to a
head next week when the football
teams representing the two classes
begin practice for the game which
the Athletic Department has arranged as an introduction to their traditional rivalry.
Coaches Gard Mallonee and Ed
Lotz of the frosh and sophs, respectively have become quite a bit "het
up" over the prospects of their teams.
As yet neither team is a known
quantity. Both coaches are pretty
confident of their team's chances—
naturally, they have to be, since
someone must maintain faith or nobody else will. This attitude on the
part of Mallonee and Lotz is quite
different than that employed by other football coaches. Lou Little of Columbia fame and Gil Dobie, formerly of Cornell, are two mentors who
are directly opposite our confident
coaches. Little and Dobie were always bemoaning their teams' chances
—but not so with our up-and-coming
members of the coaching staff—Lotz
and Mallonee.
First Year For Game
To get back to the game between
the frosh and sophs. This is one of
the first years that such a game has
ever been played. To all indications,
support is far from lacking.
The
members of each class are anxious to
win the game, since such a victory
will be the first blood drawn in the
rivalry.
Later developments between the classes is to come during
Hell Week which comes sometime in
May.

managers of both teams will be at
the gym to hand out equipment to

Hereditary Influence Factor
Children Endangered
Following Dr. Macht's address, a
paper was presented by Dr. Raymond Pearl, of the Johns Hopkins
Medical School, who said that he
had "found that a person is about
four times as likely to have tuberculosis if both his parents had it
than if neither did.
"I mean definitely to overthrow
beliefs that the extra number of tubercular children in such families
get it by contact rather than by inheritance. I analyzed tuberculosis in
564 families, numbering 3,608 per-

"The regular increase in the offspring percentage as the amount of
parental tuberculosis increases seems
impossible of rational explanation
on any other basis than that of hereditary influence.
"Increasing chance of massive con-

c

tact infection in the home cannot
reasonably explain it, in the opinion
of clinicians whom we have consulted. For plainly the chance of clinical
tuberculosis resulting from such contact infection in nothing like quantatively double what it is when only
one parent is tubercular."

was there, and every evening thereafter I was taken to the local beer
joint. I slept in Dick Snibbe's bed in
Pinkney Hall, as he was in the infirmary as a result of the attack on
Hopkins the previous Monday.
Big Time Friday
Friday night we had a big time.
All the freshmen and the two Hopkins boys dressed in pajamas for a
snake dance before the bonfire.
Burghardt and I led the procession,
which went down to cheer the Naval
Academy and they in turn cheered
us. The bonfire itself was about
thirty feet square and three stories
high and gave a great amount of
heat and light. It was still burning
at noon the next day.
The next day Jimmy Gunn drove
me back to Baltimore, and I must
say I was a trifle sorry to leave the
place where I had had such a good
time. In conclusion let me say that
the St. John's boys treated me very
well, as they went out of their way
to entertain me and introduced me to
everybody. The little bit of horseplay
to which I was subjected only added
to my enjoyment.

Rifle Club Members To
Record Weekly Scores
Preparing for the coming season,
which begins in December, members
of the Rifle Club are firing for record during this week. Records will
be kept of the best scores in each of
the three positions—prone, kneeling,
and standing. The ten men with the
best averages for these positions will
shoot for the Hopkins rifle team in
its first match, scheduled for December 14.
Returning members of the team
from last year are P. W. Guild, president of the club; Don Noonan, and
Henry Leber. All members are expected to file their scores with Sergeant Perry, so that an accurate account of their improvement from
week to week can be kept.
Later in the season, probably in
March and April, two or three shoulder to shoulder matches for the
Ra-citern Intercollegiates will be
scheduled with Maryland, Gettysburg, and the Naval Academy.
